text: five years ago Jim Woolsey former
director of the CIA and I let a
government study that found a lack of
preparedness to face catastrophic
terrorism our warnings and those of
similar groups went largely unheeded
I remember saying to somebody that we
were not going to pay attention until
there was the equivalent of a Pearl
Harbor and I last that turned out to be
correct in fact I hate to tell you this
but when we first submitted an op-ed in
the 90s this the New York Times turned
down as did another of newspaper because
they said he was just hyping the
intelligence budget well this op-ed was
written in a sense of personal anguish
after nine eleven that if we were going
to prevent this happening again we were
going to have to reorganize we're going
to have to make major changes in
government the FBI and the CIA for
example didn't really communicate very
well with each other and the various
bureaucracies which eventually were
pulled together into Homeland Security
were quite separate so the argument was
let's find ways to reorganize so that we
can get better coordination better
communication within the government well
looking back at the op-ed on how to
protect the homeland I feel that many of
the things i recommended there have been
done and that the bush and the Obama
administration deserve credit for that I
think the dangers that we think that we
solve the problem and we haven't if
terrorism is a decades-long process a
generations-long process then we have to
ask ourselves what is the strategy we
need to take internationally so that we
win the hearts and minds of mainstream
Muslims so that these radicals cannot
recruit again as they did in
a decade ago and that means we have to
resist the kind of native istic and
chauvinistic attacks on muslims which
try to divide the world into the West
versus Islam which is exactly the trap
that bin Laden wanted us to fall into
